body.p: This article explores ways of converting unstructured FrameMaker documents to a DITA XML project.

section.title: Unstructured FrameMaker to HTML to DITA
section.p: For performing this migration, your documents have to be in the ".mif" format.
If your documents are in the '.fm' format, you can use the MIF Wash Utility for converting your book into a .mif document:

The 'mif' document has to go through the following conversion and correction steps for obtaining DITA content.
Publish your Unstructured FrameMaker to HTML
In this step, the mif document is converted to HTML using the Basic HTML scenario from FrameMaker. Here are the substeps for doing it:
Create a settings file for publishing that contains mappings to HTML elements for all paragraph and character styles:
It's very important to have mappings to HTML headings elements for paragraph styles that marks headings in your document. In the example from the above image, the "Chapter", "Heading", "Title" styles are mapped to "h1" element, the "Subtitle", and "Section" styles to 'h2' element and the "Subsection" style to the 'h3' element.
The styles set on the list should be mapped to the 'li' elements. In the example, it's about the "Bullet", "Step" and "Step1" styles.
The paragraph styles without mapping are converted to HTML paragraphs. So you can skip the ones for each the mapping is not necessary. The "Body", "CellBody" and "CellHeading" style doesn't have a mapping in the example from the above image.
Publish the 'mif' document to HTML using Basic HTML:
After these substeps, an '.htm' document should result into the output directory:
Correct the resulting HTML using a custom refactoring operation The HTML document resulting from publishing required some extra processing before applying the DITA conversion. For this, do the following steps:
Download the content from the following GitHub repository:
Copy the correctHtmlFromMif.xml and correctHtmlFromMif.xsl files from the "43. FM conversion fixes" directory into the refactoring directory from the Oxygen XML Editor installation directory.
Restart Oxygen
Add the output directory that contains the HTML file to your project
In the Project view, select the HTML file, open the contextual menu, and invoke the Refactoring> XML Refactoring... action.
In the opened dialog search for the operation named Correct HTML resulting from 'mif' and apply it to the HTML document.
The applied refactoring operation corrects two problems in the HTML document:
The list items without a parent element ('ol' or 'ul')
Targets of the cross-references that have the "name" attributes from anchor elements instead of the "id" attributes
Convert HTML to DITA using Oxygen Batch Documents Converter add-on The Batch Documents Converter add-on has to be installed in Oxygen for doing this step. Follow the installation procedure from here. Before converting the document you should configure which headings are handled as topics or sections. For this use the Maximum Heading Level for Creating Topics options from the preferences page of the add-on. For converting the document do the following steps:
Select the HTML document from the Project view.
Invoke the "HTML to DITA" from the Batch Documents Converter submenu from the contextual menu.
In the opened dialog make sure the Ignore HTML 'div' elements option is checked because this element is not useful in the output and the Create DITA maps from HTML documents containing multiple headings option is checked too:
Press the Convert button.
The resulting DITA Map preserved the structure of the document, the images, tables, internal and external link:

As usual, migration from proprietary formats to XML is never perfect and manual changes need to be made. The names of the original styles are preserved on the ouputclass attributes and these can be used for adding extra processing using refactoring operations.
